rev.diff:
Line 27: Line 27:
After the [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egyptian revolution]] of 2011, el-Hamalawy was among many protesters who stormed and seized offices of the SSI in the [[Nasr City]] and was able to visit the cell where he had been imprisoned, later writing on his [[Twitter]] feed that he could not stop crying.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/world/middleeast/10cairo.html?hp | title=Egyptians Get View of Extent of Spying | publisher=The New York Times | date=9 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> "Entered the small compound where I was locked. Man, I can't believe it still... Many are literally crying. We can't find the interrogation rooms. This is a citadel."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html | title=A first step towards prosecutions? | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=6 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
After the [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egyptian revolution]] of 2011, el-Hamalawy was among many protesters who stormed and seized offices of the SSI in the [[Nasr City]] and was able to visit the cell where he had been imprisoned, later writing on his [[Twitter]] feed that he could not stop crying.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/world/middleeast/10cairo.html?hp | title=Egyptians Get View of Extent of Spying | publisher=The New York Times | date=9 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> "Entered the small compound where I was locked. Man, I can't believe it still... Many are literally crying. We can't find the interrogation rooms. This is a citadel."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html | title=A first step towards prosecutions? | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=6 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
â
Since storming the SSI offices, el-Hamalawy has become the main force behind a "naming and shaming" website targeting former SSI personnel who were involved in the alleged torture of dissidents. Their names are linked to allegations and photos.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/egypts-activists-turn-tables-on-tormentors/2011/04/30/AFEdLV1G_print.html | title=Egyptâs activists turn tables on tormentors | publisher=The Washington Post | date=13 May 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2011}}</ref>
+
Since storming the SSI offices, el-Hamalawy has become the main force behind a "naming and shaming" website "(''Piggipedia'')" targeting former SSI personnel who were involved in the alleged torture of dissidents. Their names are linked to allegations and photos.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/egypts-activists-turn-tables-on-tormentors/2011/04/30/AFEdLV1G_print.html | title=Egyptâs activists turn tables on tormentors | publisher=The Washington Post | date=13 May 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2011}}</ref>
El-Hamalawy has criticized the newly appointed [[Ministry of Justice (Egypt)|Justice Minister]] [[Mohamed Abdel Aziz el-Gendy]], for his ties to the former [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]], in relation to the freezing of assets of the ousted dictator.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/egypt-says-us-dragging-its-feet-on-freezing-mubarak-assets/2011/03/28/AFdCA35B_story.html | title=Egypt says U.S. dragging its feet on freezing Mubarak assets | publisher=The Washington Post | date=30 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> El-Hamalawy claims the the overthrow of Mubarak had been stirring as early as 2002, when pro-[[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] riots around [[Cairo University]] fought [[Central Security Forces]] chanting: "Hosni Mubarak is just like [[Ariel Sharon|Sharon]]."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/mar/02/egypt-revolution-mubarak-wall-of-fear | title=Egypt's revolution has been 10 years in the making | publisher=Guardian | date=2 March 2011 | accessdate=14 May 2011}}</ref>
El-Hamalawy has criticized the newly appointed [[Ministry of Justice (Egypt)|Justice Minister]] [[Mohamed Abdel Aziz el-Gendy]], for his ties to the former [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]], in relation to the freezing of assets of the ousted dictator.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/egypt-says-us-dragging-its-feet-on-freezing-mubarak-assets/2011/03/28/AFdCA35B_story.html | title=Egypt says U.S. dragging its feet on freezing Mubarak assets | publisher=The Washington Post | date=30 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> El-Hamalawy claims the the overthrow of Mubarak had been stirring as early as 2002, when pro-[[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] riots around [[Cairo University]] fought [[Central Security Forces]] chanting: "Hosni Mubarak is just like [[Ariel Sharon|Sharon]]."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/mar/02/egypt-revolution-mubarak-wall-of-fear | title=Egypt's revolution has been 10 years in the making | publisher=Guardian | date=2 March 2011 | accessdate=14 May 2011}}</ref>
